description: From Latin dēdicātus, past participle of dēdicō (“I dedicate, proclaim”).

adjectives.description: dedicate (comparative more dedicate, superlative most dedicate)

entries.meaning: (chiefly fantasy and paganism) One who dedicates themself, or who is dedicated, to the service of some leader, religion, etc.

verbs.description: dedicate (third-person singular simple present dedicates, present participle dedicating, simple past and past participle dedicated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set apart for a deity or for religious purposes; consecrate.
(transitive) To set apart for a special use
examples: dedicated their money to scientific research.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To commit (oneself) to a particular course of thought or action
examples: dedicated ourselves to starting our own business.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To address or inscribe (a literary work, for example) to another as a mark of respect or affection.
(transitive) To open (a building, for example) to public use.
(transitive) To show to the public for the first time
